title: Paul Allen’s Silicon Valley Home Lists for Just Under $41.5 Million
text:
In the town of Atherton, California, a Silicon Valley enclave popular with wealthy tech big-wigs and CEOs, the estate of late Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen hit the market Monday asking $41.48 million.



The billionaire and philanthropist—who died last October at 65—acquired the seven-bedroom mansion in 2013, the same year it was built, for $27 million, according to property records.



More: Michael Jordan Lists Park City, Utah, Mansion for $7.5 Million

The home is owned by a trust controlled by Allen’s sister, Jody, records with PropertyShark show.

Incredible care and attention to detail has been paid to the home, said listing agent Courtney Charney of Parc Agency. “It’s been impeccably maintained, anyone who walks in says it feels like new,” she said.



It spans more than 21,000 square feet and has high ceilings and abundant wall space—perfect for displaying art—floor-to-ceiling windows, a library and a home theater.



There’s also myriad fireplaces and a family room topped with a statement wooden ceiling. It’s touches like those that make the property unique in that it’s contemporary architecture "that exudes warmth,” Ms. Charney said. “It feels like a retreat.”



From Penta: Former Mayfair Home of Aviation Tycoon Sir Frederick Handley Page Asks £18.75M

Atherton is a town developed with one-acre parcels. “Of course, some have grown to be larger over the years,” Ms. Charney said, but the home’s 1.9 acres of land “make it a true stand out,” she said.

On the grounds are the home’s pool, outside entertaining spaces, gardens and a wild meadow.



The Paul G. Allen Family Foundation, which could not be immediately reached for comment, continues to own and operate Allen’s catalog of professional sports teams, including the Seattle Seahawks.



The home is among the assets that Allen’s estate has listed for sale, including his megayacht, Octopus, that hit the market in September for more than $300 million, and a 120-acre swath of undeveloped land in Beverly Hills that’s on the market with a $110 million price tag.



The Los Angeles Times first reported the listing.
